body:
Congratulations on being the first to notice this stuff. So much for betas. :-{
1. This is an intentional change. It remains true to the format but obviously it is a semantic difference. I don't think it should hurt anything, provided we fix #2.
2. These are both errors. The Explicit item should be Skipped, while the Ignored item should be Ignored.
3. Skipped is not new. It's used for tests skipped in a way that has penalty for the overall result. Examples are tests skipped due to a PlatformAttribute or a CultureAttribute.

I wish I could have tried the betas earlier but it's been challenging converting a large codebase from NUnit 2 to NUnit 3.

1: Makes sense.

3: Interesting - I've never used those, so that would explain why I've never seen `Skipped` before.

issue.title: name attribute in test-suite and test-results element of output xml is different to nunit 2.6.4 using nunit2-format

milestone.description:
Theme of this release is CONSOLIDATION.

We have rapidly extended the reach of NUnit in terms of platforms and features. For this release, we will fill in some gaps to consolidate those gains.

Key Planned Features:
* Allow multiple engines to co-exist, with differing sets of extensions installed.
* Increase use of extensions.
* Provide a way for NUnit to install it's own extensions.
* Provide a way for users to manage the extensions.
* Separate OneTimeSetUp and OneTimeTearDown work items.
* Implement a generalized dependency mechanism between work items.
* Implement parallel test case execution.
* Implement one of the proposed test dependency or ordering mechanisms.
* Integrate the Xamarin runners with NUnit in some way to be determined

issue.body:
I'm using nunit 3.0.1 generating output in nunit2-format.
In nunit 2.6.4 the name attribute of test-suite and test-results is the full path of the test assembly.
In nunit 3.0.1 the name attribute of test-suite is the filename of the test assembly and the name attribute of test-results is empty.

Example

```
Nunit-2.6.4\nunit-console-x86.exe "C:\test\UnitTests.dll" /runlist="C:\test\list.txt" /nologo /result="C:\test\nunit2.xml"
```

``` xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" standalone="no"?>
<!--This file represents the results of running a test suite-->
<test-results name="C:\test\UnitTests.dll" total="1" errors="0" failures="0" not-run="0" inconclusive="0" ignored="0" skipped="0" invalid="0" date="2016-01-15" time="13:42:42">
[...]
  <test-suite type="Assembly" name="C:\test\UnitTests.dll" executed="True" result="Success" success="True" time="0.504" asserts="0">
[...]
  </test-suite>
</test-results>
```

```
Nunit-3.0.1\nunit3-console.exe "C:\test\UnitTests.dll" --testlist="C:\test\list.txt" --noheader --result="C:\test\nunit3.xml";format=nunit2"
```

``` xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" standalone="no"?>
<!--This file represents the results of running a test suite-->
<test-results name="" total="1" errors="0" failures="0" not-run="0" inconclusive="0" ignored="0" skipped="0" invalid="0" date="2016-01-15" time="12:32:27">
[...]
  <test-suite type="Assembly" name="UnitTests.dll" executed="True" result="Success" success="True" time="0,691" asserts="0">
[...]
  </test-suite>
</test-results>
```

body:
I started working on this, but did not see the problem. Looking back at your example, I can see that your statement above is incorrect. You say "The [Explicit] test is given a result of Ignored, whereas the [Ignore]'d test is given a result of Skipped."

However, your XML output has the following snippets:

```
              <test-case name="NUnitSkippedTests.MyTest.Expl" executed="False" result="Skipped">
                   ...
              </test-case>
              <test-case name="NUnitSkippedTests.MyTest.Igno" executed="False" result="Ignored">
                   ...
              </test-case>
```

This is exactly what it should be. I should have read your output more closely in the first place. :-)

I no longer see anything to fix here. Do you?
Hmm, I must have misread it. I'll check when I get back to work on Monday, but I agree that given the above there is nothing to be fixed.

issue.title: Issue 1189
issue.body:
The intention here was to fix #1189 and fix #1195 in the same PR, since they appeared to impact the same code. However, it looks like #1189 is actually not a problem at all. @rprouse if you review this, hold off merging until I hear back from the author of #1189.

"While I was at it" I noticed that the V2 xml contains empty reason elements and properties for the reason a test is skipped, when the reason is not provided. This turned out to echo the 3.0 xml output, which I have fixed in the second commit.

body: This is correct, there is nothing to be fixed. My apologies. :smile:

issue.title: Loose ends
issue.body:
This PR fixes a few loose ends from earlier commits:
1. Removes commented out lazy initialization code in TestExecutionContext.Dispatcher making that property automatic.
2. Makes a TestOrderAttributeTests public
3. Applies fix for #1189 to NUnitLite as well
